noun.description: An occupation undertaken for a significant period of a person's life and with opportunities for progress.

verb.description: Move swiftly and in an uncontrolled way in a specified direction.
examples: the car careered across the road and went through a hedge

phrases: They had accordingly made their way back across the mountains, and down the rivers, and were in full career for St. Louis, when thus suddenly interrupted.
Such stoppers are invaluable, for without them it is not easy to stop a big full-rigged ship in full career without doing any damage or carrying something away.
At his heels follows the Dog, outstretched in full career.
Our centre had even captured the third enemy line, while the army on the left wing was in full career and now miles away to the west.
The Indian again came in sight, and, in full career, rushed towards him, passed him, and wheeling halted his horse.
origin: Mid 16th century (denoting a road or racecourse): from French carrière, from Italian carriera, based on Latin carrus wheeled vehicle.
